{{Taxobox | image = Leucocoprinus_brebissonii-2.jpg | image_caption = Fruit body | image2 = Leucocoprinus_brebissonii-1.jpg | image2_caption = Cap detail | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Agaricaceae]] | genus = ''[[Leucocoprinus]]'' | species = '''''L. brebissonii''''' | binomial = ''Leucocoprinus brebissonii'' | binomial_authority = ([[Louis-Luc Godey|Godey]]) [[Marcel Locquin|Locq.]] (1943) | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = ''Lepiota brebissonii'' Godey (1874)
''Leucocoprinus otsuensis'' [[Tsuguo Hongo|Hongo]] (1953)
''Lepiota otsuensis'' (Hongo) Hongo (1959) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Leucocoprinus brebissonii'' | whichGills = adnexed | capShape = conical | capShape2 = flat | hymeniumType = gills | stipeCharacter = ring | ecologicalType = saprotrophic | sporePrintColor = white | howEdible = poisonous }} {{Portal|Fungi}} '''''Leucocoprinus brebissonii''''' is a species of [[fungus]] in the [[Agaricaceae]] family. It was first described by [[Louis-Luc Godey]] in 1874 as ''Lepiota brebissonii'', and moved to ''[[Leucocoprinus]]'' by [[Marcel Locquin]] in 1943. It is commonly called the '''skullcap dapperling''' due to its distinctive pattern on the cap. Until recently, this mushroom was only found in Europe but over the last few years has been identified in the [[Pacific Northwest]]. ==Description== ''Leucocoprinus brebissonii'' is a small, delicate, mushroom with white and brittle [[trama (mycology)|flesh]]. Its [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] ({{convert|2|to|3|cm|in|1|abbr=on}}) starts out conical expanding to a plane in age, with a dark brown/gray center that breaks up and radiates outwards on a white and deeply striated background. The white [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] of ''L. brebissonii'' is long and slender ({{convert|4.5|to|6|cm|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} by {{convert|3|to|6|mm|sigfig=2|abbr=on}}), equal or slightly clavate. It usually has a ring present, but due to its fragile nature sometimes it is rubbed or washed off. Its [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] are crowded, white and narrowly attached to the stem, but occasionally detach in age. The [[basidiospore|spores]] (9 to 12 µm x 5.5 to 7 µm) are white and have a pronounced [[germ pore]], elliptical or almond shape. ==Distribution and habitat== ''Leucocoprinus brebissonii'' is found in Europe and North America from summer to fall, where it grows in the soil in woods with [[deciduous]] trees. ==Edibility== ''Leucocoprinus brebissonii'' is suspected to be poisonous. Its taste and smell are nondescript. ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite book |title=Les Hyménomycètes ou Description de tous les Champignons qui Croissent en France |author=Gillet, Claude-Casimir |volume=1 |year=1878 |page=64 |language=French}} {{cite journal |author=Loquin, Marcel |title=Étude du développement des spores du genre ''Leucocoprinus'' Pat. |journal=Bulletin mensuel de la Société Linnéenne de Lyon |volume=12 |pages=35–43 |year=1943 |language=French}} {{cite book |last1= Trudell |first1= Steve |last2= Ammirati |first2= Joe |authorlink1= Steve Trudell |authorlink2= Joe Ammirati |title= Mushrooms of the Pacific Northwest |publisher= [[Timber Press]] |page=77 |year = 2009 |isbn = 978-0-88192-935-5}} {{cite web |url=http://www.mycobank.org/MycoTaxo.aspx?Link=T&Rec=287721 |title=''Leucocoprinus brebissonii'' (Godey) Locq. 1943 |publisher=International Mycological Association |work=MycoBank |accessdate=2011-05-03}} {{cite web |title=''Leucocoprinus brebissonii'' |author=Phillips, Roger |url=http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6328~gid~~source~gallerydefault.asp |work=Rogers Mushrooms |accessdate=2011-05-03 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120823102408/http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6328~gid~~source~gallerydefault.asp |archivedate=2012-08-23 }} }} ==External links== *{{IndexFungorum| }} *[https://mushroomobserver.org/observer/index_observation?q=4eIb ''Leucocoprinus brebissonii'' observations at Mushroom Observer] {{Commons category}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q6534109}} [[Category:Fungi described in 1874]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]]
